Authors: Sarauskis, E; Vaiciukevicius, E; Sakalauskas, A; Martinkus, M
Author Full Names: Sarauskis, Egidijus; Vaiciukevicius, Edvardas; Sakalauskas, Antanas; Martinkus, Mindaugas
Article Title: Investigation of Soil Cultivation Impact on Winter Wheat Growth and Grain Yield
Source Title: RURAL DEVELOPMENT 2009 PROCEEDINGS, VOL 4, BOOK 2, PROCEEDINGS
Conference Title: 4th International Scientific Conference on Rural Development
Conference Location: Lithuanian Univ Agr Akad, Noreikiskes, LITHUANIA
Author Keywords: soil cultivation and sowing technology; soil properties; seedbed; winter wheat; yield
Keywords Plus: TECHNOLOGICAL PARAMETERS; SOWING DEPTH; COULTERS
Abstract: The research of technological processes of winter wheat sowing using various agricultural systems were performed in Marijampole and Pasvalys regions. The key research objective was to test winter wheat seed introduction with the help of disc coulters into ploughed and no-tillage hard clay loam soils of different regions, and their impact on plant development and yield structure indices. The impact of different soil cultivation methods and sowing technologies on soil characteristics, seed bed preparation and seed introduction, germination and yield structure indices were investigated. Seed bed preparation and seed introduction indices were determined by Sweden scientists using Kritz/Hakannson method. Soil cultivation and seed introduction depth evenness, and soil grading composition were estimated. Tests disclosed that in order to introduce winter wheat seed properly with disc drill coulters in no-tillage hard clay loam soil, the yield vegetative residues should be introduced into the soil before the sowing. In dry soil (less than 3% moisture content) big hard lump structure is formed thus the seeds are not always duly introduced in proper depth with drill coulters. When the impact of different agricultural systems on the seed introduction of winter wheat, seed development and yield structure indices were estimated it became obvious that their influence was not significant. Meteorological conditions, soil characteristics and other criteria have greater impact.

Authors: Sha, ZQ; Long, CZ; Wang, XY
Author Full Names: Sha, Zhenquan; Long, Chengzhi; Wang, Xiaoyu
Article Title: An Empirical Study on Comprehensive Model of Brand Communication
Source Title: EIGHTH WUHAN INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON E-BUSINESS, VOLS I-III
Conference Title: 8th Wuhan International Conference on E-Business
Conference Sponsor: China Univ Geosci,CICEB,Coll Econ & Management,Coll Business,Alfred Univ
Author Keywords: brand identity; brand image; brand gap
Abstract: Brand identity is a business point of view on the value of the brand, as well as the significance of the external image of the description of the enterprise hope that the consumer perceived brand image, brand and the consumer is on the elements of a comprehensive brand perception is subjective perception of the consumer level. Based on Coop and Kapferer's brand identity process model, this paper develops the model through substituting the environment exogenous variable by brand relationship. The brand image's dimension is based on Biel Brand Structural Model, and brand relationship's dimension is based on the relation type, the questionnaire is formed. The survey is carried among Beijing, Shanghai and Guangzhou and 329 samples were collected. Result indicates that the brand relationship has a significant positive effect on the brand image, among them, the effect on the user is the highest the corporate image is next to, and the product image is the lowest, but all the effects are significant. The empirical study develops understanding on attributes of brand gap which is helpful to reduce or even to eliminate brand gap and improve brand loyalty.

Authors: Tang, DJ; Chen, J
Author Full Names: Tang, Daijian; Chen, Jue
Article Title: Applications of Mass Customization into Service Delivery System Design: a new research domain
Source Title: EIGHTH WUHAN INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON E-BUSINESS, VOLS I-III
Conference Title: 8th Wuhan International Conference on E-Business
Conference Sponsor: China Univ Geosci,CICEB,Coll Econ & Management,Coll Business,Alfred Univ
Author Keywords: Mass customization; Modularity; Postponement; Service delivery system
Keywords Plus: OPPORTUNITIES; MANAGEMENT
Abstract: The paper intends to present clear pictures of research evolution in two research domain based on a thorough literature review: the service system design and mass customization areas, and identifies a necessity for integrating these two areas, namely adopting the concepts of mass customization to guide the service delivery system design to cope with the traditional operation dilemma. This could lead to a new research area for exploration with both great industrial and academic significance. The paper finally presents brief research suggestions to stimulate further research efforts in application of mass customization into the service delivery system design at both macro and micro level.

Author Full Names: Xiao, Qun
Article Title: A New Date Attachable E-check System with Reusable Refunds
Source Title: EIGHTH WUHAN INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON E-BUSINESS, VOLS I-III
Conference Title: 8th Wuhan International Conference on E-Business
Conference Sponsor: China Univ Geosci,CICEB,Coll Econ & Management,Coll Business,Alfred Univ
Author Keywords: e-check; partially blind signature; RSA; reusable refund
Keywords Plus: CASH
Abstract: The transaction date is increasing important to the customers and the merchants due to the interest of e-cash. This paper presents a new date attachable e-check system based on the scheme proposed by Fan. In our scheme the attached date can be modified subject to changing conditions of transaction. Besides, a new method has been given to generate the refund e-check which can be used just as the initial check as payments in future transactions. And two solutions are used to replace the matured e-check. Our scheme provides unforgeability, anonymity, atomicity and avoiding double spending under standard assumptions.

Article Title: The Research of Knowledge Transfer in Virtual Enterprise based on Evolutionary Games Theory
Source Title: EIGHTH WUHAN INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON E-BUSINESS, VOLS I-III
Conference Title: 8th Wuhan International Conference on E-Business
Conference Sponsor: China Univ Geosci,CICEB,Coll Econ & Management,Coll Business,Alfred Univ
Author Keywords: virtual enterprise; knowledge transfer; coopetition; evolutionary game theory
Keywords Plus: PERFORMANCE; IMPACT; TEAMS
Abstract: The members of knowledge transfer in virtual enterprise will take different strategies for their own profits. So analyze the game relationship of members in virtual enterprise is necessary. This paper research the knowledge transfer in virtual enterprise with evolutionary game theory. The result shows that cooperation and competition are concomitant in virtual enterprise. Besides, the factors such as punishment level for non-cooperation, existing knowledge resources of each members, knowledge profit and initial willingness to cooperate are impact on the knowledge transfer in virtual enterprise. This research will be propitious to establish an effective mechanism for knowledge transfer in virtual enterprise.

Article Title: Ontological Evaluation of Chinese Regional Knowledge Competence: Empirical Analysis by Panel Datum From 2004 to 2006

Abstract: Based on research achievements review of knowledge competence, knowledge competence framework model is put forward and ontological evaluation index system is constructed. After collection of panel datum of Chinese 31 regions from 2004 to 2006, ontology evaluation of Chinese regional knowledge competence is empirically analyzed by entropy weight Promethee II, and knowledge competence superior coefficients and grades of Chinese 31 regions from 2004 to 2006 are obtained. Conclusion is drawn that Chinese regional knowledge competence tends to equilibrium but is lacks of development.

Authors: Zhu, HW; Huang, MX
Author Full Names: Zhu, Huawei; Huang, Minxue
Article Title: Customer Attitudes toward Credit Card in an Emerging Market
Source Title: EIGHTH WUHAN INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON E-BUSINESS, VOLS I-III
Conference Title: 8th Wuhan International Conference on E-Business
Conference Sponsor: China Univ Geosci,CICEB,Coll Econ & Management,Coll Business,Alfred Univ
Author Keywords: credit cards; emerging market; usage frequency; payment percentage
Abstract: Despite the huge quantity of credit cards in Chinese market most of them are in inactive usage. Thus, how to stimulate customers to use credit cards should be the focus for both academic research and management practice. This study examines the impacts of both customers' positive and negative attitude towards credit cards on their usage of credit cards, usage frequency and payment percentage. The results indicate that convenience benefits is the most important motivation for customers to use credit cards in the emerging market and the potential risks are the main barrier for them to use credit cards as common payment tool. Therefore, credit card issuing bank should make efforts from these two aspects.

Authors: Graham, C; Higuera, L; Lora, E
Author Full Names: Graham, Carol; Higuera, Lucas; Lora, Eduardo
Article Title: WHICH HEALTH CONDITIONS CAUSE THE MOST UNHAPPINESS?
Author Keywords: health; happiness; adaptation; valuing health conditions
Keywords Plus: HAPPINESS; STATES; VALUATION
Abstract: This paper assesses the effects of different health conditions on happiness. Based on new data for Latin America, we examine the effects of different conditions across age, gender, and income cohorts. Anxiety and pain have stronger effects than physical problems, likely because people adapt better to one-time shocks than to constant uncertainty. The negative effects of health conditions are very large when compared with the effects of income on happiness. And, while higher peer income typically elicits envy, better peer health provides positive signals for life and health satisfaction. Health norms vary widely across countries. Authors: De Sinopoli, F; Ferraris, L; Iannantuoni, G
Author Full Names: De Sinopoli, Francesco; Ferraris, Leo; Iannantuoni, Giovanna
Article Title: The effect of ideology on policy outcomes in proportional representation systems
Abstract: In this paper we propose a model in which there are ideological and strategic voters who vote under proportional rule. We prove that the behavior of ideological voters matters for the determination of the outcome. We show that a subset of strategic voters partially counteracts the votes of the ideological voters. Authors: Kuhn, M; Wrzaczek, S; Prskawetz, A; Feichtinger, G
Author Full Names: Kuhn, Michael; Wrzaczek, Stefan; Prskawetz, Alexia; Feichtinger, Gustav
Article Title: Externalities in a life cycle model with endogenous survival
Author Keywords: Demand for health; Externality; Life cycle-model; Optimal control; Tax-subsidy; Value of life
Keywords Plus: UNCERTAIN LIFETIME; HEALTH; LONGEVITY; DEMAND; INVESTMENTS; CONSUMPTION; CONGESTION; RESISTANCE; FAMILY
Abstract: We study socially vs individually optimal life cycle allocations of consumption and health, when individual health care curbs own mortality but also has a spillover effect on other persons' survival. Such spillovers arise, for instance, when health care activity at aggregate level triggers improvements in treatment through learning-by-doing (positive externality) or a deterioration in the quality of care through congestion (negative externality). We combine an age-structured optimal control model at population level with a conventional life cycle model to derive the social and private value of life. We then examine how individual incentives deviate from social incentives and how they can be aligned by way of a transfer scheme. The age-patterns of socially and individually optimal health expenditures and the transfer rate are derived. Numerical analysis illustrates the working of our model. (C) 2011 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

Authors: Boone, J; van Ours, JC; Wuellrich, JP; Zweimüller, J
Author Full Names: Boone, Jan; van Ours, Jan C.; Wuellrich, Jean-Philippe; Zweimueller, Josef
Article Title: Recessions are bad for workplace safety
Author Keywords: Workplace accidents; Economic incentives; Cyclical fluctuations
Keywords Plus: RATES
Abstract: Workplace accidents are an important economic phenomenon. Yet, the pro-cyclical fluctuations in workplace accidents are not well understood. They could be related to fluctuations in effort and working hours, but workplace accidents may also be affected by reporting behavior. Our paper uses unique data on workplace accidents from an Austrian matched worker-firm dataset to study in detail how economic incentives affect workplace accidents. We find that workers who reported an accident in a particular period of time are more likely to be fired later on. And, we find support for the idea that recessions influence the reporting of moderate workplace accidents: if workers think the probability of dismissals at the firm level is high, they are less likely to report a moderate workplace accident. (C) 2011 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

Authors: Boswijk, HP; van der Weide, R
Author Full Names: Boswijk, H. Peter; van der Weide, Roy
Article Title: Method of moments estimation of GO-GARCH models
Conference Title: Conference on Factor Structures for Panel and Multivariate Time Series Data
Conference Sponsor: Maastricht Res Sch Econom Technol & Org (METEOR),Dept Quantitative Econom
Author Keywords: Multivariate GARCH; Factor models; Method of moments; Common principal components
Keywords Plus: MULTIVARIATE; IDENTIFICATION; VOLATILITY; COMPONENTS; MATRICES
Abstract: We propose a new estimation method for the factor loading matrix in generalized orthogonal GARCH (GO-GARCH) models. The method is based on eigenvectors of suitably defined sample autocorrelation matrices of squares and cross-products of returns. The method is numerically more attractive than likelihood-based estimation. Furthermore, the new method does not require strict assumptions on the volatility models of the factors, and therefore is less sensitive to model misspecification. We provide conditions for consistency of the estimator, and study its efficiency relative to maximum likelihood estimation using Monte Carlo simulations. The method is applied to European sector returns. (C) 2010 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

Authors: Braakmann, N
Author Full Names: Braakmann, Nils
Article Title: The causal relationship between education, health and health related behaviour: Evidence from a natural experiment in England
Author Keywords: Education; Health; Socio-economic gradient; Education gradient; Compulsory schooling
Keywords Plus: MORTALITY; SMOKING
Abstract: I exploit exogenous variation in the likelihood to obtain any sort of educational qualification between January- and February-born individuals for 13 academic cohorts in England. For these cohorts compulsory schooling laws interacted with the timing of the CSE and O-level exams to change the probability of obtaining a qualification by around 2-3 percentage points. I then use data on individuals born in these two months from the British Labour Force Survey and the Health Survey for England to investigate the effects of education on health using being February-born as an instrument for education. The results indicate neither an effect of education on various health related measures nor an effect on health related behaviour, e.g., smoking, drinking or eating various types of food. (C) 2011 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

Authors: Hallin, M; Liska, R
Author Full Names: Hallin, Marc; Liska, Roman
Article Title: Dynamic factors in the presence of blocks
Conference Title: Conference on Factor Structures for Panel and Multivariate Time Series Data
Conference Sponsor: Maastricht Res Sch Econom Technol & Org (METEOR),Dept Quantitative Econom
Author Keywords: Panel data; High dimensional time series data; Dynamic factor model; Dynamic principal components
Keywords Plus: FACTOR MODEL; MONETARY-POLICY; FORECASTING INFLATION; PRINCIPAL COMPONENTS; EURO AREA; NUMBER; ARBITRAGE; REAL
Abstract: Macroeconometric data often come under the form of large panels of time series, themselves decomposing into smaller but still quite large subpanels or blocks. We show how the dynamic factor analysis method proposed in Forni et al. (2000), combined with the identification method of Hallin and Liska (2007), allows for identifying and estimating joint and block-specific common factors. This leads to a more sophisticated analysis of the structures of dynamic interrelations within and between the blocks in such datasets, along with an informative decomposition of explained variances. The method is illustrated with an analysis of a dataset of Industrial Production Indices for France, Germany, and Italy. (C) 2011 Published by Elsevier B.V.

Authors: Woo, JM; Kim, W; Hwang, TY; Frick, KD; Choi, BH; Seo, YJ; Kang, EH; Kim, SJ; Ham, BJ; Lee, JS; Park, YL
Author Full Names: Woo, Jong-Min; Kim, Won; Hwang, Tae-Yeon; Frick, Kevin D.; Choi, Byong Hwi; Seo, Yong-Jin; Kang, Eun-Ho; Kim, Se Joo; Ham, Byong-Joo; Lee, Jun-Seok; Park, Yu Lee
Article Title: Impact of Depression on Work Productivity and Its Improvement after Outpatient Treatment with Antidepressants
Author Keywords: cost; depression; lost productive time; productivity; presenteeism
Keywords Plus: PERFORMANCE QUESTIONNAIRE HPQ; HEALTH-ORGANIZATION HEALTH; ECONOMIC BURDEN; UNITED-STATES; COSTS; CARE; US; DISORDERS; EMPLOYERS; INTERVIEW
Abstract: Objective: Depressive disorders influence socioeconomic burden at both the individual and organizational levels. This study estimates the lost productive time (LPT) and its resulting cost among workers with major depressive disorder (MDD) compared with a comparison group. It also estimates the change in productivity after 8 weeks of outpatient psychiatric treatment with antidepressants. Methods: Working patients diagnosed with MDD without other major physical or mental disorders were recruited (n = 102), along with age-and sex-matched healthy controls from the Seoul Metropolitan area (n = 91). The World Health Organization's Health and Work Performance Questionnaire and the Hamilton Rating Scale for Depression were utilized to measure productivity and severity of depression, respectively, at baseline and at 8 weeks of treatment. Results: The LPT from absenteeism and presenteeism (reduced performance while present at work) was significantly higher among the MDD group. Workers with MDD aver-aged costs due to LPT at 33.4% of their average annual salary, whereas the comparison group averaged costs of 2.5% of annual salary. After 8 weeks of treatment, absenteeism and clinical symptoms of depression were significantly reduced and associated with significant improvement in self-rated job performance (31.8%) or cost savings of $7508 per employee per year. Conclusions: We confirmed that significant productivity loss arises from MDD and that this loss can be reduced with psychiatric intervention after a time period as short as 8 weeks. Mental health professionals should work with employers to devise a cost-effective system to provide workers with accessible quality care.

Authors: Aouani, Z; Cornet, B
Author Full Names: Aouani, Zaier; Cornet, Bernard
Article Title: Reduced equivalent form of a financial structure
Author Keywords: Restricted participation; Portfolio constraints; Financial exchange economy; Reduced financial structure; Equivalent financial structure; Arbitrage-free prices; Consumption equilibrium
Keywords Plus: INCOMPLETE MARKETS; GENERIC EXISTENCE; RESTRICTED PARTICIPATION; COMPETITIVE-EQUILIBRIUM; MODEL; ECONOMIES
Abstract: We consider the two-date model of a financial exchange economy (epsilon, F), with agents' portfolio restrictions either represented by finitely many linear inequality constraints or satisfying Hart's (1974) Weak No Market Arbitrage condition. The economy (epsilon, F) is shown to have the same consumption equilibria as a reduced economy (epsilon, F), for which the set of admissible portfolio allocations is bounded. Building upon the equilibrium existence result for reduced financial economies (epsilon, F) (Aouani and Cornet, 2009), we then deduce the existence of equilibra of (epsilon, F), under standard assumptions on the consumption side and under the aforementioned assumption on the financial side. (C) 2011 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

Authors: Chambers, CP; Healy, PJ
Author Full Names: Chambers, Christopher P.; Healy, Paul J.
Article Title: Reversals of signal-posterior monotonicity for any bounded prior
Author Keywords: Signal extraction; Bayes' rule; MLRP; Stochastic dominance; Updating
Abstract: Paul Milgrom [Milgrom, P.R., 1981. Goods news and bad news: representation theorems and applications. The Bell Journal of Economics 12, 380-391] showed that if the strict monotone likelihood ratio property (MLRP) does not hold for a conditional distribution then there exists some non-degenerate prior and pair of signals where the higher-signal posterior does not stochastically dominate the lower-signal posterior. We show that for any non-degenerate prior with bounded support there exists a conditional distribution (satisfying several natural properties) and pair of signals such that the lower signal's posterior stochastically dominates that of the higher signal. Thus, for every bounded prior, higher signals may represent strictly worse news. (C) 2011 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
